Functionalized hollow double-shelled polymeric nano-bowls as effective heterogeneous organocatalysts for enhanced catalytic activity in asymmetric Michael addition Zhiwei Zhao a Dandan Feng b Guangxin Xie a Xuebing Ma a ⁎ a Key Laboratory of Applied Chemistry of Chongqing Municipality, College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Southwest University, Chongqing 400715, PR China Key Laboratory of Applied Chemistry of Chongqing Municipality College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering Southwest University Chongqing 400715 PR China b Zhengzhou Institute of Technology, Henan 450044, PR China Zhengzhou Institute of Technology Henan 450044 PR China ⁎ Corresponding author. Graphical abstract Owing to the thinner shell and a void between two semi-shells, functionalized hollow double-shelled polymeric nano-bowl as an effective heterogeneous catalyst significantly improved the mass transfer of reactants and displayed higher catalytic activity than hollow nano-bowl with on void and hollow nanosphere in asymmetric Michael addition. A facile and robust strategy to fabricate organocatalyst-functionalized hollow double-shelled nano-bowl was developed for the first time by hard-templating synthesis. After the core was etched by DMF, the outer shell thicknesses below 50 nm and above 50 nm deformed into hollow nano-bowl and hollow nanosphere, respectively. Furthermore, the outer shell with the average thickness of 20–50 nm deformed into hollow double-shelled nano-bowl with a void between two semi-shells. However, the shell with the thicknesses below 20 nm severely deformed into hollow nano-bowl with no void owing to the overlapping of two semi-shells. Compared with hollow nanosphere and nano-bowl with no void, hollow double-shelled nano-bowl displayed superior catalytic performances owing to the thin shell thickness and a void between two semi-shells. In heterogeneous asymmetric Michael addition, the double-shelled nano-bowl exhibited good to excellent yields (86–98%), stereoselectivities (syn/anti = 81–93/19–7 and 93–99%ee syn) and good reusability. Keywords Hollow doubled-shelled nano-bowl Hollow nano-bowl with no void Hollow nanosphere Enhanced activity Asymmetric heterogeneous Michael addition Abbreviations AA acrylamide St styrene PS poly(styrene/acrylic acid) PVA poly(vinylalcohol) ProTMS (S)-α, α-bis(4-vinylphenyl) prolinol trimethylsilyl ether EGDMA ethanol ethyleneglycol dimethacrylate KPS potassium peroxydisulfate Poly(St-co-ProTMS-co-AA) HBs hollow nano-bowls Poly(St-co-ProTMS-co-AA)HNs hollow nanospheres Poly(St-co-ProTMS) HBs(a) standard condition Poly(St-co-ProTMS) HBs(b) without AA Poly(St-co-ProTMS-co-AA) HBs(c) increased ProTMS Poly(St-co-ProTMS-co-AA) HBs(d) doubled KPS Poly(St-co-ProTMS-co-AA) HBs(e) doubled PS Poly(St-co-ProTMS-co-AA) HBs(f) doubled EGDMA Poly(St-co-ProTMS-co-AA) HNs (a) DMSO/H2O = 2/1 Poly(St-co-ProTMS-co-AA) HNs (b) DMSO/H2O = 1/1 Poly(St-co-ProTMS-co-AA) HNs (c) DMSO/H2O = 1/2 1 Introduction Hollow spheres have attracted broad interests in recent years owing to their interior void structure, the most attractive characteristics of which are well-defined morphology, high specific surface area, low density and unique optical, electric and magnetic property [1–7]. All of these fascinating properties endow them with superior potential applications including energy storage and conversion [8–12], biomedical applications [13], catalysis [14–17], environmental science [18–20], and so forth. Recently, the bowl-like particles with a broken centrosymmetry as a class of asymmetric structure have drawn attentions due to the anisotropic effects, thus allowing the new or enhanced properties in drug delivery [21,22], battery [23–25] and catalysis [26–30]. Furthermore, many efforts have been devoted to the development of hollow double-shelled nano-bowls, including nitrogen-doped carbon particles via pyrolysis using kippah vesicle as template [31], NiO nanosheets@carbon particles via thermal treatment using hollow polystyrene as template [32], polysilsesquioxane particle via toluene as liquid soft template [33], carboxyl-containing polymer particles via alkali post-treatment [34] and carbon nanobowls via hydrothermal method [35]. In the field of heterogeneous catalysis, the fabrication of the catalysts with controlled shapes and well-defined facets or surface structures is one of the most crucial issues for the design and development of highly efficient heterogeneous catalysts [36–39]. Tuning the surface morphology of heterogeneous catalysts allows the preferential exposure of catalytic sites, which can maximize the number of active sites available to reactants [40], improve the activity and also mediate the reaction route to achieve a higher selectivity for a particular chemical reaction [7,41]. As interest in asymmetric organocatalysis is on the increase as a new and powerful methodology in organic chemistry, the immobilization of organocatalysts has attracted increasing attentions [42–45]. Recently, more attentions are paid to the enhanced catalytic performances in heterogeneous organocatalysis by means of the attractive and outstanding characteristics of hollow sphere to ensure low environmental impact and achieve more sustainable catalytic processes [46–49]. In terms of thinner shell thickness, hollow double-shelled nano-bowl is more favorable to seepage velocity of reactants than hollow nanosphere. However, the organo-functionalized fabrication of hollow double-shelled nano-bowl remains a great challenge due to the low control over precise bowl shape, poorly understood mechanisms and general synthetic strategy. Additionally, most of organocatalysts have a negative influence on the controlled fabrication of nano-bowl in hard templating process owing to its polarity, and cannot tolerate high temperature in commonly used hydrothermal synthesis. In this study, novel hollow double-shelled nano-bowls [Poly(St-co-ProTMS-co-AA) HBs], functionalized by versatile Jorgensen-Hayashi organocatalyst [(S)-α, α-bis(4-vinylphenyl)prolinol trimethylsilyl ether, ProTMS] into the thin outer shell, was developed by hard-templating method for the first time. As shown in Scheme 1 a, the hollow double-shelled nano-bowls were prepared by controlling the outer shell thickness via the first coating of ProTMS with acrylamide (AA) and styrene (St) on the surface of poly(styrene/acrylic acid) (PS) nanosphere in 0.5 wt% poly(vinyl-alcohol) (PVA) emulsifier to form core-shelled nanosphere through dispersion copolymerization, followed by selective removal of PS core in DMF. Moreover, to elucidate the superior catalytic performance of hollow double-shelled nano-bowl, ProTMS-functionalized hollow nanosphere [Poly(St-co-ProTMS-co-AA) HNs] was also prepared as a control sample by altering the addition sequence of DMSO and H2O (Scheme 1b). In heterogeneous asymmetric Michael addition, hollow double-shelled nano-bowls displayed excellent catalytic activity superior to hollow nano-bowl with no void and hollow nanosphere due to the thinner shell thickness and slightly higher specific surface area and pore volume. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials and sample characterization Styrene was purified by distillation under reduced pressure before use. (S)-α, α-bis(4-vinylphenyl)prolinol trimethylsilyl ether (ProTMS) was synthesized according to the reference (ESI†) [46]. The other chemicals were used as received without any further purification. 1H and 13C NMR spectra were conducted using a Bruker av-600 NMR instrument, in which all chemical shifts were reported down-field in ppm relative to the hydrogen and carbon resonances of TMS. Elemental analysis was obtained using a vario Micro cube elemental analyzer. The morphology was observed by JSM-6510LV scanning electron microscopy and Tecnai G2 F20 transmission electron microscope, operated at 20 kV/15 mA and 200 kV respectively. N2 adsorption–desorption isotherm was carried out at 77.4 K using an Autosorb-1 apparatus (Quantachrome), in which the sample was degassed at 105 °C for 12 h before measurement, and the specific surface area and pore volume were calculated by BET method and BJH model, respectively. FT-IR spectroscopy was performed on a Perkin-Elmer model GX spectrometer using KBr pellet. Thermogravimetry-differential thermal analysis was carried out on a thermal analyzer (SBTQ600) at a heating rate of 10 °C min−1 from 40 to 600 °C using N2 as protective gas (100 mL min−1). The anti/syn ratios of Michael adducts were determined by 1H NMR according to peak area ratios of proton in CHO group, and the enantiomeric excesses (%ee) were monitored by Agilent LC-1200 HPLC with a 220 nm UV–vis detector using Daicel Chiralpak chiral OD-H column (4.6 mm × 25 cm), eluting with n-hexane/isopropanol (90/10) at a flow rate of 0.5 mL min−1 under 20 °C. 2.2 Preparation of hollow double-shelled nano-bowls A N2-filled three-necked flask (100 mL) containing AA (216.0 mg, 3.0 mmol) was charged with 0.5 wt% poly(vinyl-alcohol) (PVA)-contained DMSO suspension (10 mL) of PS template (250.0 mg) by syringe, stirred till AA was completely dissolved, added 0.5 wt% PVA-contained DMSO solution (16 mL) and heated to 55 °C. To the suspension was added DMSO solution (4 mL) containing St (104.0 mg, 1.0 mmol), ProTMS (150.0 mg, 0.4 mmol) and ethanol ethyleneglycol dimethacrylate (EGDMA, 160.0 mg, 0.4 mmol), well-dispersed under ultrasound irradiation for 30 min and then injected aqueous 0.5 wt% PVA-contained DI water (27 mL) by syringe. After well-mixed for 10 min, potassium peroxydisulfate (KPS, 40.0 mg, 0.15 mmol) aqueous solution (3 mL) was injected by syringe. The translucent emulsion was heated up to 80 °C and carried out for 24 h under N2 atmosphere. The resulting mixture was cooled to 25 °C and added ethanol (60 mL). The isolated faint yellow core-shelled nanospheres PS@Poly(St-co-ProTMS-co-AA) were well-dispersed in 20 mL DMF, irradiated for 15 min by ultrasound, stirred for 3 h and separated by centrifugation. The solid was repeatedly dealt with DMF several times till no turbid phenomenon was observed upon adding the centrifugate into water. Finally, hollow double-shelled nano-bowls Poly(St-co-ProTMS-co-AA) HBs(a) (140.5 mg) was obtained by washing with ethanol three times (10 mL × 3) and air drying. According to the same above-mentioned procedure, the recipes such as reaction time, PS, KPS, ProTMS, EGDMA and AA were concocted to prepare the following hollow nano-bowls: Poly(St-co-ProTMS) HBs(b) without AA monomer, Poly(St-co-ProTMS-co-AA) HBs(c) with increased ProTMS by 50% (225 mg), Poly(St-co-ProTMS-co-AA) HBs(d) with doubled KPS (80 mg), Poly(St-co-ProTMS-co-AA) HBs(e) with doubled PS (500 mg) and Poly(St-co-ProTMS-co-AA) HBs(f) with doubled EGDMA (320 mg). 2.3 Preparation of hollow nanosphere A N2-filled three-necked flask (100 mL) containing AA (216.0 mg, 3.0 mmol) was charged 0.5 wt% PVA-contained H2O/DMSO suspension (10 mL, v/v = 1/4) of PS template (250.0 mg) by syringe. After AA was completely dissolved, 0.5 wt% PVA-contained DI water (15 mL) and 0.5 wt% PVA-contained DMSO (28 mL) were added, well-dispersed and heated up to 55 °C. To the suspension was added DMSO solution (4 mL) containing EGDMA (160.0 mg, 0.4 mmol), ProTMS (150.0 mg, 0.4 mmol) and St (104.0 mg, 1.0 mmol), well-dispersed under ultrasound irradiation for 30 min and injected aqueous KPS solution (3 mL, 40.0 mg, 0.15 mmol). The resulting translucent emulsion was heated up to 80 °C and stirred for 24 h under N2 atmosphere. The resulting solution was cooled to 25 °C and added ethanol (60 mL). The isolated faint yellow core-shelled PS@Poly(St-co-ProTMS-co-AA) was well-dispersed in 20 mL DMF, irradiated for 15 min by ultrasound, stirred for another 3 h and separated by centrifugation. The solid was repeatedly dealt with DMF several times till no turbid phenomenon was observed upon adding the centrifugate into water. Finally, hollow nanosphere Poly(St-co-ProTMS-co-AA) HNs(a) (316.0 mg) was obtained by washing with ethanol three times (10 mL × 3) and air drying. According to the same above-mentioned procedure, Poly(St-co-ProTMS-co-AA) HNs(b) and Poly(St-co-ProTMS-co-AA) HNs(c) were prepared in the mixed DMSO/H2O solvents (v/v = 1/1 and 1/2), respectively. 2.4 Procedure for heterogeneous asymmetric Michael addition The reaction mixture of trans-β-nitrostyrene (20.0 mg, 0.13 mmol), 2-FC6H4CO2H (5.5 mg, 0.04 mmol, 30 mol%) and Poly(St-co-ProTMS-co-AA) HBs(a) (50.0 mg, 15 mol%) in CHCl3 (2.5 mL) was stirred at 25 °C for 20 min. Then propionaldehyde (64.0 mg, 1.1 mmol) was added, well-dispersed under ultra-sound irradiation for 5 min and further stirred at 25 °C. After the completion of Michael addition monitored by TLC, ethanol (2.5 mL) was added and the hollow nano-bowl Poly(St-co-ProTMS-co-AA) HBs(a) was separated from the reaction mixture by centrifugation. The recovered Poly(St-co-ProTMS-co-AA) HBs(a) was reused directly for the next catalytic cycle. The centrifugate was concentrated and purified by silica gel column chromatography using petroleum ether/ethyl acetate (v/v = 5/1) as eluents to afford the adduct (2R, 3S)-2-methyl-4-nitro-3-phenyl-butanal (27.5 mg, 99%). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Fabrication of hollow double-shelled nano-bowls and hollow nanosphere The representative hollow double-shelled nano-bowl Poly(St-co-ProTMS-co-AA) HBs(a) and hollow nanosphere Poly(St-co-ProTMS-co-AA) HNs(a) were prepared under the same total volumes of mixed DMSO/H2O solvents and moles of monomers according to Scheme 1. The only difference between two routes in the fabrication process of nano-bowl and nanosphere was the feeding order of DMSO and H2O, which would significantly affect the emulsification of monomers and the growth of copolymer on the surface of PS core with the mean particle size of 307 nm. When PS and monomers were first well-dispersed in 0.5 wt% PVA-contained DMSO and then emulsified in 0.5 wt% PVA-contained DI water, the obtained core-shelled nanosphere with the mean particle size of 328 nm (Fig. S6b) had an outer polymeric shell with the thickness about 21 nm, which was roughly estimated by the difference in mean particle size between core-shelled nanospheres (Fig. S9a) and PS core (Fig. S1). Unfortunately, the outer shell could not be discriminated from the TEM image owing to the thin shell thickness (inset of Fig. 1 a). After PS cores were removed by etching with DMF, the thin outer shells could not provide an sufficient sustenance to maintain original spherical shape and deformed into hollow double-shelled nano-bowl Poly(St-co-ProTMS-co-AA) HBs(a) (Fig. 1b). Furthermore, when the volume ratios of H2O to DMSO (v/v = 1/2) were altered to v/v = 1/1 and 2/1 with the unchanged total volume, the nano-bowls with different deformation degrees were observed. Upon increasing the volume ratios of H2O to DMSO, the formation of emulsion model (b) with more monomers around PS core was favored [50], and the thicker shell with better holding power resulted in the shorter slit of nano-bowl (Fig. S8b, c). In the other hand, when PS and various monomers were emulsified in 0.5 wt% PVA-contained mixed H2O/DMSO solvents (v/v = 1/2), the core-shelled nanosphere possessed the thicker shell with the mean particle size of about 376 nm from the SEM images (Fig. S6a), which was clearly observed in the TEM image (inset of Fig. 1c). After being treated with DMF several times, the core-shelled nanosphere with the mean shell thickness of about 69 nm produced the hollow nanosphere Poly(St-co-ProTMS-co-AA) HNs(b) (Fig. 1d). Altering the volume ratios of H2O to DMSO to v/v = 1/1 and 2/1, the same spherical morphologies were also achieved (Fig. S7). However, in H2O/DMSO mixed solvents (v/v = 2/1), the particle size of hollow nanosphere became uneven (Fig. S7a). Based on the fact that the morphologies of hollow nano-bowl and hollow nanosphere could be regulated by feeding order of DMSO and H2O, two possible emulsion models, model (a)–monomers without PS core and model (b)–monomers around PS core (Fig. 2 ), were proposed to be formed in 0.5 wt% PVA-contained DMSO/H2O emulsion system. When PS and monomers were first well-dispersed in DMSO and then emulsified in H2O, the emulsion model (a) was favoured, and the emulsion model (b) containing less monomers around PS core resulted in a thinner outer shell. After the removal of PS core by DMF, the outer shell without sufficient support force would collapse and ultimately deformed into the hollow double-shelled nano-bowl. However, emulsifying PS and monomers in mixed H2O/DMSO solvents, the emulsion model (a) was not favoured, and the emulsion model (b′) with more monomers around PS core resulted in a thicker outer shell. The thicker shell with a sufficient support force ultimately produced hollow nanosphere after the removal of PS core. 3.2 Morphological evolution of hollow double-shelled nano-bowls To clarify the morphological evolution of hollow double-shelled nano-bowl, the morphological change in the whole fabrication process was monitored by SEM (Fig. 2). When the well-dispersed PS core and monomers in DMSO were emulsified in 0.5 wt% PVA-contained water at 55 °C, the emulsion models (a) and (b) were formed simultaneously, which was elucidated by the formation of core-shelled nanospheres (300–345 nm) and nanoparticles (20–40 nm) (Fig. 2c). The core-shelled nanospheres (Fig. 2e) and nanoparticles (Fig. 2d) could be conveniently isolated by centrifugal separation. After PS cores were etched with DMF, the thin outer shells with the mean thickness of about 21 nm could not withstand the balance under the combined action of centrifugal force (FC) and osmotic pressure P toward the interior owing to centrifugation and solvent evaporation [33], and ultimately deformed into hollow double-shelled nano-bowls (Fig. 2f). The nano-bowls and leached PS (Fig. 2g) were isolated by centrifugal separation. When no turbid solution was observed upon adding several drops of centrifugate into water, the nano-bowls (Fig. 2 h) and PS cores were completely isolated each other. Finally, anhydrous ethanol was chosen as a finishing agent to improve the bowl-shaped morphology due to its better volatility than DMF. After dried in air, the ProTMS-functionalized nano-bowl Poly(St-co-ProTMS-co-AA) HBs(a) (Fig. 2i) with a void between two semi-shells was obtained. 3.3 Catalytic activity of hollow double-shelled nano-bowl and hollow nanosphere In the model asymmetric Michael addition of propionaldehyde to trans-β-nitrostyrene, the peak area ratio (SP/SM) of the product (2R, 3S)-2-methyl-4-nitro-3-phenylbutanal (SP) to the reactant trans-β-nitrostyrene (SM) in HPLC spectra, plotted versus reaction times (0–3.5 h), were used as parameters to evaluate catalytic activities of hollow double-shelled nano-bowl Poly(St-co-ProTMS-co-AA) HBs(a) and hollow nanosphere Poly(St-co-ProTMS-co-AA) HNs(a). SP/SM ratio–time as kinetic data could effectively eliminate the error sources resulted from inaccurate weighing and sampling volume in analysis. Furthermore, Sp/Sm ratio–time was better for amplifying their activity differences. From Fig. 3 , both hollow double-shelled nano-bowl and hollow nanosphere produced the Michael adduct with excellent stereoselectivities (>98%ee syn) during the whole process. However, the peak area ratios (SP/SM) revealed that there was a great difference in catalytic activity between nano-bowl and nanosphere. The hollow nanosphere promoted the Michael addition with a very low peak area ratio (SP/SM = 0.6) for 3.5 h (Table S5) and afforded the Michael product in 96% yield with an excellent stereoselectivity (syn/anti = 92:8, 97%ee) for 48 h. Delightedly, the hollow double-shelled nano-bowl exhibited the significantly enhanced catalytic activity with SP/SM = 14.7 for 3.5 h (Table S5) and afforded the Michael adduct in 98% yield with excellent stereoselectivity (syn/anti = 93:7, 99%ee) for 5 h. To account for the higher catalytic activity of hollow double-shelled nano-bowl than hollow nanosphere, the differences in chemical composition and pore structure were explored by IR spectra, elemental analysis, N2 adsorption–desorption isotherm and TGA. From IR spectra, the successful covalent attachment of organocatalyst ProTMS into the polymeric framework of hollow nano-bowl and hollow nanosphere was clearly corroborated by the characteristic stretching vibrations of OSi and CSi at 1029 cm−1, 840 cm−1 and flexural vibration of methyl in Si(CH3)3 moiety at 1250 cm−1 (Fig. S2) [46,51]. Based on the nitrogen contents by elemental analysis (0.65% and 0.58%), the loading capacities of ProTMS in hollow nano-bowl and nanosphere were calculated to be 0.41 mmol g−1 and 0.46 mmol g−1, respectively (Table S1). The more loaded ProTMS in hollow nanosphere than nano-bowl was also ascertained by TGA due to the more silicon-related residual mass (21.6%) of hollow nanosphere at 600 °C (Fig. S4). In the other hand, both hollow nano-bowl and hollow nanosphere possessed the similar micro/mesoporous structures from the pore size distribution (Fig. S3). However, the hollow nano-bowl had the higher BET-specific surface area (30 m2 g−1) and pore volume (8.4 × 10−2 cc g−1) than the hollow nanospheres (22 m2 g−1 and 7.3 × 10−2 cc g−1) (Table S2). Based on the above-mentioned characterizations, it was concluded that the better catalytic activity of hollow nano-bowl than hollow nanosphere under the same used amount of ProTMS was attributed to two major factors. One was the slightly higher BET-specific surface area and pore volume of hollow nano-bowl than hollow nanosphere, which provided the high accessibility of reactants to active catalytic sites and fast diffusion of products out from the shell. The other factor was the thinner shell thickness of hollow nano-bowl (21 nm) than hollow nanosphere (69 nm). According to Darcy’s law, the seepage velocity of reactants in heterogeneous medium is inversely proportional to the length of transmission path. Therefore, the lower transmission resistance was met for the reactants in the thinner shell of hollow nano-bowl at the same internal and external concentration difference [52], and then the reactants transmitted through the thinner shell of nano-bowl in a faster migration rate than that in thicker shell of hollow nanosphere. 3.4 Morphological control of hollow nano-bowls In view of the great influence of shell thickness of nano-bowl on catalytic activity in heterogeneous Michael addition, the several parameters such as reaction time and used PS, KPS, ProTMS, EGDMA, AA were adjusted to achieve various hollow nano-bowls with different shell thicknesses. The SEM and TEM images of various hollow nano-bowls with the different shell thicknesses and deformation degrees were shown in Fig. 4 and Fig. 5 , respectively. We herein introduced a parameter “x” – a length ratio (L/ R) of the placket length (L) of nano-bowl to the distance between two vertexes of semi-shells (R) in TEM image–to represent the deformation degrees of nano-bowls (inset of Fig. 5) [53]. Due to the deformation of nano-bowls, the shell thicknesses of various nano-bowls were estimated by comparison of the average particle sizes of core-shelled nanospheres with that of PS core from SEM images. From Fig. 5a, Poly(St-co-ProTMS-co-AA) HBs(a) with the average thickness of about 21 nm (Fig. S9a) had a circular opening, symmetrical shell, semi-spherical profile and void between two semi-shells in the vertical view of a single bowl (inset of Fig. 5a). Its deformation degree (x) was estimated to be 1.4. When no AA was added in fabrication process, the core-shelled nanospheres possessed the thinner shells with the average thickness of about 8 nm (Fig. S9b). Due to the weakened support force owing to the thinner shell and hydrogen-bonding deficiency in the absence of AA, the nano-bowl Poly(St-co-ProTMS) HBs(b) exhibited a great deformation degree with no void (R = 0) between two semi-shells (inset of Fig. 5b). Upon increasing the used amount of ProTMS, the outer shell of core-shelled nanosphere with 0.74 mmol g−1 loading capacity of ProTMS increased to the average thickness of about 42 nm (Fig. S9c). However, owing to the flexibility of bulky ProTMS, the thick shell was still unable to provide a sufficient support force to form hollow nanosphere and ultimately deformed into bi-caved or tri-caved hollow nano-bowl (Figs. 4c, 5c). The deep polymerization, initiated by doubled KPS, also produced the thicker outer shell with the average thickness of about 35 nm (Fig. S9d), which deformed into hollow double-shelled nano-bowl Poly(St-co-ProTMS-co-AA) HBs(a) with a smaller deformation degree (x = 0.4) (Fig. 5d). Moreover, the doubled PS core resulted in the thin shell with the average shell thickness of about 17 nm (Fig. S9e). In this case, two semi-shells clung closely each other and resulted in no void between two semi-shells (Fig. 5e). Hence, the nano-bowl Poly(St-co-ProTMS-co-AA) HBs(e) displayed the high deformation degree (R = 0) (Fig. 4e). Finally, the increased EGDMA favored the formation of thick outer shell and resulted in the increased average shell thickness of about 50 nm (Fig. S9f). From the SEM image, the obtained double-shelled nano-bowl Poly(St-co-ProTMS-co-AA) HBs(f) exhibited small deformation degree (Fig. 4f). The placket length (L) was too short to be observed by TEM image (Fig. 5f). In conclusion, the shell thickness was responsible for the deformation degrees of core-shelled nanosphere after the removal of PS core. The outer shells with the average thicknesses in the range of 20–50 nm could not provide sufficient support forces to balance the action of centrifugal force and osmotic pressure toward the interior, and ultimately deformed into hollow double-shelled nano-bowl. Especially, the shell thickness below 20 nm resulted in a great deformation degree with overlapping semi-shells and no void between two semi-shells. 3.5 Catalytic performances of various hollow nano-bowls The heterogeneous Michael addition of propionaldehyde with trans-β-nitrostyrene to produce (2R, 3S)-2-methyl-4-nitro-3-phenylbutanal was also selected as model reaction to further investigate the differences in the catalytic performances of various hollow nano-bowls at the same catalyst loading (50 mg). It was found that both hollow multi-caved nano-bowl Poly(St-co-ProTMS-co-AA) HBs(c) (Fig. 6 a) and hollow double-shelled nano-bowl Poly(St-co-ProTMS-co-AA) HBs(a) (Fig. 6b) exhibited outstanding catalytic activities with excellent enantioselectivities (>98%ee syn) during the whole process. However, Poly(St-co-ProTMS-co-AA) HBs(c) (0.74 mmol g−1 of ProTMS) showed the slightly higher catalytic activities than Poly(St-co-ProTMS-co-AA) HBs(a) (0.41 mmol g−1 of ProTMS), which implied that 30 mol% of Poly(St-co-ProTMS-co-AA) HBs (c) (SP/SM = 30.3 at 4 h) only achieved the similar efficiency as 15 mol% of Poly(St-co-ProTMS-co-AA) HBs(a) (SP/SM = 24.0 at 4 h). In fact, their differences in specific surface areas (21 m2 g−1 vs. 30 m2 g−1) and pore volume (0.096 cc g−1 vs. 0.084 cc g−1) between them were very small. Therefore, it was conjectured that the high efficiency of Poly(St-co-ProTMS-co-AA) HBs(a) was mainly attributed to the thinner average shell thickness (21 nm vs. 42 nm), which resulted in the better seepage quantity of reactants and products through the polymeric shell. Moreover, hollow nano-bowls Poly(St-co-ProTMS) HBs(b) without AA and Poly(St-co-ProTMS-co-AA) HBs(e) with doubled PS core contained 0.50 mmol g−1 and 0.36 mmol g−1 of loaded ProTMS similar as Poly(St-co-ProTMS-co-AA) HBs(a), and possessed the higher specific surface areas (35 m2 g−1 and 31 m2 g−1), pore volumes (0.12 cc g−1 and 0.14 cc g−1) and thinner average shell thickness (8 nm and 17 nm) than Poly(St-co-ProTMS-co-AA) HBs(a) (30 m2 g−1, 0.08 cc g−1 and 21 nm) (Table S4). Unexpectedly, both exhibited the significantly lower catalytic activities with small peak area ratios (SP/SM < 4 at 4 h) and inferior enantioselectivities (92–98%ee syn) (Fig. 6c, d). The reason behind the sharp decrease in catalytic performances was attributed to no void between the overlapping semi-shells (Fig. 5b and e), which was not advantageous to the seepage of reactants and products through the shell owing to the thick shell thickness and lack of internal and external concentration difference. Furthermore, upon doubling used amount of EGDMA, Poly(St-co-ProTMS-co-AA) HBs (f) with a low deformation degree possessed the lower specific surface area (26 m2 g−1), poorer pore volume (0.07 cc g−1) and thicker average shell thickness (50 nm). These factors were not advantageous to mass transfer of reactants accessible to catalytic sites and responsible for the lowest conversion of trans-β-nitrostyrene with SP/SM = 0.35 at 4 h (Fig. 6e). Briefly, based on the above-mentioned morphology-activity relationship of bowl-like heterogeneous organocatalyst in Michael addition, the hollow double-shelled nano-bowl with the thin shell and a void between two semi-shells is the most suitable morphology for catalyst support, because the thin shell thickness is beneficial to mass transfer of reactants accessible to catalytic sites under internal and external concentration difference. However, the severely deformed nano-bowl with no void between two semi-shells possessed the inferior catalytic activity owing to the thick thickness of overlapping semi-shells and lack of internal and external concentration difference. 3.6 Catalytic performance of hollow double-shelled nano-bowl in Michael addition 3.6.1 Optimization of catalytic conditions Based on the aforementioned catalytic performance of various hollow nano-bowls during the whole process, the hollow double-shelled nano-bowl Poly(St-co-ProTMS-co-AA) HBs(a) with the excellent stereoselectivity (syn/anti = 93:7, 99%ee) and high catalytic activity (98% yield for 5 h) was chosen for the further optimization of catalytic conditions such as co-catalyst, temperature and catalyst amount. The catalytic performances of Poly(St-co-ProTMS-co-AA) HBs(a) in the asymmetric heterogeneous Michael addition of propionaldehyde with trans-β-nitrostyrene were shown in Table 1 . Firstly, it was found that the acid strengths of co-catalysts such as 3-NO2C6H4CO2H (pKa = 2.45), 2-F-C6H4CO2H (pKa = 3.27) and C6H4CO2H (pKa = 4.21) had a great effect on catalytic performances. Among them, 2-FC6H4CO2H (pKa = 3.27) was proved to be the best effective co-catalyst with the excellent catalytic performances (91% for 4 h, syn/anti = 93/7, 98% ee, Table 1, entry 6). Upon increasing the dosage of 2-FC6H4CO2H to 30 mol%, the higher yield (>98%) with the excellent diastereoselectivity (syn/anti = 93/7) and enantioselectivity (98%ee syn) could be achieved (entry 7). Disappointedly, when the dosage of propionaldehyde was halved, the yield of adduct decreased to 87% with the reduced stereoselectivity (syn/anti = 92/8 and 95%ee, entry 8). Similarly, the halved Poly(St-co-ProTMS-co-AA) HBs(a), assisted by 2-FC6H4CO2H (30 mol%), also produced the adduct in the decreased yield (85%), although the excellent stereoselectivity including diastereoselectivity (syn/anti = 93/7) and enantioselectivity (98%ee syn) remained unchanged (entry 12). Upon decreasing temperature to −5 °C, the Michael addition proceeded at a considerably lower rate, requiring up to 10 h for the achievement of adduct in 88% yield (entry 11). On the contrary, the elevated temperature (40 °C) resulted in the poor diastereoselectivity (syn/anti = 76/34) and enantioselectivity (92%ee syn) (entry 9). 3.6.2 Scope of Michael addition Under optimum catalytic conditions, the scope of substrates was expanded to a wide variety of trans-β-nitrostyrenes bearing electron-donating (CH3, OCH3) and electron-withdrawing (–X) substituents at the o, m, p-positions of benzene ring. From Table 2 , the electronic and steric effects of the substituents attached on benzene ring on the catalytic performances of Poly(St-co-ProTMS-co-AA) HBs(a) were precisely delineated by yield, reaction time, syn/anti and%ee syn. The trans-β-nitrostyrenes bearing electron-withdrawing substituents attached on the p-position of benzene ring (p-F, p-Cl and p-Br) afforded the corresponding adducts in high yields (>96%) with the good to excellent stereoselectivities (syn/anti = 86–92/14–8, 93–99%ee syn, entries 2, 4, 5) within 4 h. However, the trans-β-nitrostyrenes bearing 4-OCH3 electron-donating substituent displayed the inferior catalytic activity, requiring 24 h to achieve the 86% yield with high stereoselectivities (syn/anti = 89/11, 97%ee syn, entry 6). It was worthwhile to note that the trans-β-nitrostyrenes bearing 2-Cl electron-withdrawing substituent required 12 h to achieve the 95% yield with syn/anti = 88/12 and 93%ee syn owing to the vicinal hindrance of 2-Cl substituent (entry 3). The similar phenomenon of vicinal hindrance was also observed for 2-OCH3 and 2-CH3 substituents, which also needed the prolonged times (28 h and 24 h) to achieve the good yields (88% and 90%) (entries 8, 10). Owing to the disappeared conjugation of 3-OCH3 and hyper conjugation of 3-CH3 with CC bonds in nitroalkene, trans-β-(3-methoxyphenyl)nitroalkene (entry 7) and trans-β-(3-methylphenyl)nitroalke-ne (entry 9) with low electronic densities of CC bonds afforded the corresponding adducts with increased activities in 94% and 96% yields within 7 h and 9 h, respectively. Furthermore, the trans-β-nitroalkenes bearing furan-2-yl and naphthalen-2-yl were also tested in the catalytic Michael addition (entries 11, 12). Similarly, owing to the increased electronic densities of CC bonds resulted from π-π conjugation, the prolonged times (10 h and 15 h) were needed to achieve the 97% and 90% yields with excellent stereoselectivities (95%ee and 98%ee), respectively. Compared with other such heterogeneous organocatalysts [51,54–59], the as-synthesized hollow double-shelled nano-bowl possessed superior catalytic performances including activity and steroselectivity. To the best of our knowledge, it could be seen as the most efficient heterogeneous Jørgensen–Hayashi organocatalysts to date in terms of excellent catalytic performances and well-defined hollow morphology. Furthermore, the hollow double-shelled nano-bowl (15 mol%) could achieve the same high catalytic performances as water-soluble homogeneous counterpart (3 mol%) within 5 h for trans-β-nitrostyrene [60]. Especially for trans-β-nitrostyrene derivatives bearing p-Br and o-Cl substituents, the reaction times were shortened and higher yields of Michael adducts were obtained. 3.7 Reusability of hollow double-shelled nano-bowl After the completion of Michael addition, hollow double-shelled nano-bowl Poly(St-co-ProTMS-co-AA) HBs(a) was recovered by centrifugation and reused directly for the next catalytic cycle. From Fig. 7 a, the nano-bowl maintained the similar high levels of diasteroselectivities (syn/anti = 93–90/7–10) and enantioselectivities (97–98%ee) in the six consecutive cycles. Unfortunately, the significant loss in catalytic activity was observed after the sixth run. The prolonged time (24 h) was needed to achieve the good yield (85%). To understand the reason for the decreased catalytic activity, the changes of the 6th-reused nano-bowl in chemical composition, pore structure and morphology were monitored by elemental analysis, TGA, N2 adsorption–desorption isotherm and TEM. Based on the increased nitrogen content (0.92% → 1.76%) stemmed from nitrogenous compounds, it was elucidated that the trans-β-nitroalkene and its adduct were absorbed into the porous framework of nano-bowl, which was also convinced by the decreased BET-specific surface area (25.0 m2 g−1), pore volume (0.07 cc g−1) and the increased micropores (Fig. S12b). From the TEM image shown in Fig. 7b, the 6th-recycled nano-bowl remained its original monodisperse morphology of hollow bowl-shape and no agglomeration occurred. However, some semi-shells of double-shelled nano-bowl further collapsed, even overlapped. Moreover, the EDS spectra showed that the atomic percent of silicon on the surface decreased from 0.32% to 0.21% (Fig. 7c), which illustrated that the partial hydrolysis of trimethylsilyl ether in ProTMS happened during the recycled catalytic processes. Based on the above-mentioned changes in chemical composition, pore structure and morphology, it was conjectured that the multi-factors including adsorbed impurities, overlapping semi-shells and partial hydrolysis of trimethylsilyl ether were responsible for the decreased catalytic performance of 6th-reused Poly(St-co-ProTMS-co-AA) HBs(a). 4 Conclusions To improve mass transfer of reactants in solid catalyst skeleton has always been one of the most consistently pursued research topics in the field of heterogeneous catalysis. Due to the interior void structure, hollow nano-spheres have received increasing interests in enhancing catalytic activity of heterogeneous catalyst. In this paper, a novel type of hollow organocatalyst-functionalized double-shelled nano-bowl with the thinner shell was developed to facilitate the mass transport of reactants. In asymmetric Michael addition, these hollow double-shelled nano-bowls presented superior catalytic performances compared with hollow nanosphere and ever-reported supported organocatalyst. Moreover, the morphological control of hollow nano-bowls and the effect of shell thickness on catalytic performance were investigated in detail. Such hollow nano-bowls with no void between two semi-shells were inferior to hollow double-shelled nano-bowls owing to the thick shell thickness of overlapping semi-shells and lack of internal and external concentration difference. It was believed that the enhanced catalytic efficiency resulted from the hollow structure and thin shell, which gives rise to better mass transfer, will benefit more extensive applications in heterogeneous catalysis. coredata.dc:description: A facile and robust strategy to fabricate organocatalyst-functionalized hollow double-shelled nano-bowl was developed for the first time by hard-templating synthesis. After the core was etched by DMF, the outer shell thicknesses below 50 nm and above 50 nm deformed into hollow nano-bowl and hollow nanosphere, respectively. Furthermore, the outer shell with the average thickness of 20–50 nm deformed into hollow double-shelled nano-bowl with a void between two semi-shells. However, the shell with the thicknesses below 20 nm severely deformed into hollow nano-bowl with no void owing to the overlapping of two semi-shells. Compared with hollow nanosphere and nano-bowl with no void, hollow double-shelled nano-bowl displayed superior catalytic performances owing to the thin shell thickness and a void between two semi-shells. In heterogeneous asymmetric Michael addition, the double-shelled nano-bowl exhibited good to excellent yields (86–98%), stereoselectivities (syn/anti = 81–93/19–7 and 93–99%ee syn) and good reusability.
coredata.dc:title: Functionalized hollow double-shelled polymeric nano-bowls as effective heterogeneous organocatalysts for enhanced catalytic activity in asymmetric Michael addition
